material.mattext: The Narrator creates Tyler Durden as an idealized alter ego embodying everything he wishes he could be. According to Gross (2015), what emotion regulation failure precipitates this dissociation?
Excessive cognitive reappraisal
Over-reliance on situation selection
Chronic suppression of authentic emotional experience combined with alienation, leading to psychological fragmentation
Attentional deployment to external stimuli

Correct!

The Narrator suppresses his authentic emotions while living an unfulfilling consumerist life. Gross's research shows chronic suppression is costly and ultimately ineffective. The Narrator can't express his rage, frustration, or authentic desires through normal channels, so they fragment off into Tyler - a persona who can express everything the Narrator suppresses. Alienation from authentic self, combined with chronic suppression, creates conditions for dissociation.

The correct answer is C.

The Narrator suppresses his authentic emotions while living an unfulfilling consumerist life. Gross's research shows chronic suppression is costly and ultimately ineffective. The Narrator can't express his rage, frustration, or authentic desires through normal channels, so they fragment off into Tyler - a persona who can express everything the Narrator suppresses. Alienation from authentic self, combined with chronic suppression, creates conditions for dissociation.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: The Narrator doesn't reappraise; he suppresses and denies.
  • B: He doesn't select situations; he passively accepts his life.
  • D: Tyler represents MORE than redirected attention; he's a fragmented identity.
The Narrator obsessively purchases IKEA furniture to feel "complete." According to McKnight & Kashdan (2009), why does consumerism fail as a source of purpose?
Material goods are inherently meaningless
The Narrator's specific choices are aesthetically poor
Purpose requires self-organizing systems that create sustained meaning; consumption provides hedonic pleasure but not the enduring direction characteristic of purpose
Only relationships can provide purpose

Correct!

McKnight & Kashdan describe purpose as a self-organizing system that provides sustained direction. Consumption provides hedonic spikes (pleasure from acquiring) but not eudaimonic meaning (sense that life matters). Each purchase provides temporary satisfaction that fades, requiring more consumption. This differs from purpose, which generates sustained meaning and direction. The Narrator's "nest" can never provide what purpose would.

The correct answer is C.

McKnight & Kashdan describe purpose as a self-organizing system that provides sustained direction. Consumption provides hedonic spikes (pleasure from acquiring) but not eudaimonic meaning (sense that life matters). Each purchase provides temporary satisfaction that fades, requiring more consumption. This differs from purpose, which generates sustained meaning and direction. The Narrator's "nest" can never provide what purpose would.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Goods CAN have meaning in context; the issue is their failure to provide PURPOSE specifically.
  • B: The specific aesthetics are irrelevant to the psychological failure.
  • D: Purpose can come from many sources; relationships aren't uniquely required.

Tyler Durden states: "It's only after we've lost everything that we're free to do anything." According to Shermer's (2002) analysis of belief formation, what makes this philosophy appealing despite its irrationality?
The statement is actually rational
Tyler is inherently charismatic
The philosophy offers a simple explanation for complex dissatisfaction and an actionable solution - characteristics that make beliefs "sticky" regardless of truth value
Audiences are uniquely susceptible to nihilism

Correct!

Shermer describes "sticky" beliefs as those offering simple explanations and clear actions. Tyler's philosophy: (1) explains why people are unhappy (possessions), (2) offers simple solution (destroy possessions), and (3) provides clear action (fight, destroy). This simplicity and actionability make the belief appealing regardless of whether it's true. Complex dissatisfaction gets a simple diagnosis and treatment plan.

The correct answer is C.

Shermer describes "sticky" beliefs as those offering simple explanations and clear actions. Tyler's philosophy: (1) explains why people are unhappy (possessions), (2) offers simple solution (destroy possessions), and (3) provides clear action (fight, destroy). This simplicity and actionability make the belief appealing regardless of whether it's true. Complex dissatisfaction gets a simple diagnosis and treatment plan.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: The philosophy has logical problems; its appeal isn't based on rationality.
  • B: Charisma helps spread the message but doesn't explain WHY the message resonates.
  • D: The mechanisms apply to any appealing belief, not just nihilism.
The film suggests that chronic insomnia triggered the Narrator's dissociation. According to research on sleep deprivation and reality testing, this portrayal is:
Completely inaccurate - sleep deprivation has no psychological effects
Partially accurate - severe sleep deprivation impairs reality monitoring and can contribute to dissociative and psychotic symptoms
Perfectly accurate - insomnia always causes DID
Relevant only to the film's narrative

Correct!

Sleep deprivation research shows impaired reality monitoring, increased susceptibility to hallucinations, and cognitive deficits that could contribute to dissociative experiences. The film's portrayal is PARTIALLY accurate: chronic insomnia could contribute to reality testing failures and dissociative phenomena. However, it's not PERFECTLY accurate because insomnia alone doesn't typically cause full dissociative identity disorder; other factors (trauma, predisposition) typically contribute.

The correct answer is B.

Sleep deprivation research shows impaired reality monitoring, increased susceptibility to hallucinations, and cognitive deficits that could contribute to dissociative experiences. The film's portrayal is PARTIALLY accurate: chronic insomnia could contribute to reality testing failures and dissociative phenomena. However, it's not PERFECTLY accurate because insomnia alone doesn't typically cause full dissociative identity disorder; other factors (trauma, predisposition) typically contribute.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Sleep deprivation has well-documented psychological effects.
  • C: DID is complex and multi-determined; insomnia alone isn't sufficient.
  • D: The portrayal has scientific basis, not just narrative convenience.

Fight Club members follow increasingly destructive orders without question. According to social dominance research (Pratto et al., 1994), what does Project Mayhem reveal about the relationship between rejecting one hierarchy and creating another?
Anarchism prevents new hierarchies from forming
Fight Club successfully eliminates social dominance
Anti-hierarchy movements often reproduce dominance structures; SDO may manifest as rejection of some hierarchies while embracing others
Only corporations create hierarchies

Correct!

Pratto et al.'s SDO framework predicts that dominance orientation is a stable trait that finds expression across contexts. Fight Club's members reject corporate/consumer hierarchy but create a NEW hierarchy with Tyler at top. The anti-hierarchy rhetoric masks a new power structure. This illustrates how rejecting one hierarchy doesn't eliminate the psychological tendency toward hierarchy; it redirects it. Project Mayhem has ranks, rules, and punishments - it's a hierarchy denouncing hierarchy.

The correct answer is C.

Pratto et al.'s SDO framework predicts that dominance orientation is a stable trait that finds expression across contexts. Fight Club's members reject corporate/consumer hierarchy but create a NEW hierarchy with Tyler at top. The anti-hierarchy rhetoric masks a new power structure. This illustrates how rejecting one hierarchy doesn't eliminate the psychological tendency toward hierarchy; it redirects it. Project Mayhem has ranks, rules, and punishments - it's a hierarchy denouncing hierarchy.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: The film directly contradicts this by showing new hierarchy emerging.
  • B: Project Mayhem IS an expression of SDO, just directed differently.
  • D: The film shows that anti-corporate movements can also create hierarchies.
